definition: to sit on the fence/to take both sides in a dispute
(Tw) saddle horse/mounted soldier
to sit astride/to ride (a horse, bike etc)/classifier for saddle horses
wall/CL:面[mian4],堵[du3]
variant of 牆|墙[qiang2], wall

sentences.english: The liberals prefer to sit on the fence while the other parties fight it out.
sentences.chinese: 自由党宁可抱骑墙态度，坐待其他党派去斗争到底。
别在所有问题上都持骑墙态度呀。

sentences.english: The " in-between" will fade from your view.
sentences.chinese: 骑墙中庸的状态将从你的视野中退出。

sentences.english: Sooner or later you'll have to come down on one side or the other; you can't just sit on the fence.
sentences.chinese: 你迟早会倒向这边或那边，不能只是采取骑墙态度。

definition: (idiom) to hesitate/to remain undecided
sb who goes whichever way the wind blows/sb with no mind of their own/easily swayed person/opportunist
to watch the fires burning across the river/to delay entering the fray until all others have been exhausted by fighting amongst themselves (idiom)
to bend with the wind
sit on the mountain and watch the tigers fight/watch in safety whilst others fight then reap the rewards when both sides are exhausted (idiom)
centrist/the centrist faction
indecisive/wavering
to take the lead/to be first to (do sth)/to pioneer
to try to smooth things over/to paper over the issues/to gloss things over
to sit and await success or failure (idiom); to wait to see the outcome of a fight before taking sides/to sit on the fence
a wise man looks after his own hide (idiom)/to put one's own safety before matters of principle
serve Qin in the morning Chu in the evening (idiom); quick to switch sides
lit. see the wind and set the helm (idiom); fig. to act pragmatically/to be flexible and take advantage of the situation
two-faced, three knives (idiom); double-cross/double dealing and back stabbing
outward devotion but inner opposition (idiom); to pay lip service/to agree overtly, but oppose in secret
to act as one thinks fit/to have one's own way
